standard_metadata.standard_description: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.

question.content: Eliana drove her car $81 \text{ km}$ and used $9$ liters of fuel. She wants to know how many kilometers $(x)$ she can drive on $22$ liters of fuel. She assumes her car will continue consuming fuel at the same rate.  **How far can Eliana drive on $22$ liters of fuel?**   $\text{ km}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of kilometers to liters must be equivalent.
We can represent this relationship in a table.  Kilometers (km) | Liters (L) :- | :- $81\text{ km}$ | $9\text{ L}$ $x\text { km}$| $22\text { L}$

We can use the table to solve for  $x$:  Kilometers (km) | Liters (L) :- | :- $81\text{ km}$ | $9\text{ L}$ $\downarrow\times \dfrac{22}{9}$ | $\downarrow\times \dfrac{22}{9}$ $x\text { km}$| $22\text { L}$
We need to multiply $81\times \dfrac{22}9$ to find $x$.  $81\times \dfrac{22}{9} =\dfrac{ \stackrel{9}{\cancel{81}} \times~ 22  }{  1 \times\underset{1}{\cancel{9}}} =\dfrac{198}1=198$
Eliana can drive $198\text{ km}$ using $22$ liters of gas.

question.content: Elio makes candles that are $14\text{ cm}$ tall. Each candle burns $8$ hours before going out. He is wondering how many hours a $21\text{ cm}$ tall candle can burn for.  He assumes that the relationship between the height of a candle and number of hours it burns $(h)$ is proportional.  **How long can a $21 \text{ cm}$ tall candle burn for?**   hours

hints.content: We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{\text{Size of candle B}}{\text{Size of candle A}} = \dfrac{\text{Duration of candle B}}{\text{Duration of candle A}}$
Substituting values from the problem, we get this:  $\dfrac{21\text{ cm}}{14\text{ cm}} = \dfrac{h\text{ hours}}{8\text{ hours}}$
Now, solve the proportion for $h$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{21}{14} &= \dfrac{h}{8} \\\\ \dfrac{3}{2} &= \dfrac{h}{8} \\\\ 8 \cdot \dfrac{3}{2} &= h \\\\ \dfrac{24}{2} &= h \\\\ 12 &= h \end{align}$
A $21 \text{ cm}$ tall candle can burn for $12$ hours.

question.content: Vito uses $9$ liters of water to water $24$ flower pots.  He is wondering how many liters of water $(w)$ it would take to water $40$ flower pots. He assumes he'll use the same amount of water on each pot.  **How many liters of water does it take to water $40$ flower pots?**   liters

hints.content: We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{\text{Water needed for 40 pots}}{\text{Water needed for 24 pots}} = \dfrac{\text{40 pots}}{\text{24 pots}}$
Substituting values from the problem, we get this:  $\dfrac{w \text{ liters}}{9\text{ liters}} = \dfrac{40\text{ pots}}{24\text{ pots}}$

Now, solve the proportion for $w$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{w}{9} &= \dfrac{40}{24} \\\\ \dfrac{w}{9} &= \dfrac{5}{3} \\\\ w &= \dfrac{5}{3} \cdot 9 \\\\ w &= \dfrac{5\cdot 9}{3} \\\\ w &= \dfrac{5\cdot \stackrel{3}{\cancel9} }{\underset{1}{\cancel3}} \\\\ w &= \dfrac{5 \cdot 3}{1} \\\\ w &= \dfrac{15}{1} \\\\ w &= 15 \end{align}$
It takes $15$ liters of water to water $40$ flower pots.

question.content: Chef Rita is cooking for a Sunday brunch. She knows that $22$ pancakes can feed $8$ people. She is wondering how many people $(p)$ she can feed with $55$ pancakes. She assumes each person eats the same quantity of pancakes.  **How many people can Rita feed with $55$ pancakes?**   people

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of pancakes to people must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{55\text{ pancakes}}{p \text{ people}} = \dfrac{22\text{ pancakes}}{8\text{ people}}$
Let's solve for $p$:  $\dfrac{55\text{ pancakes}}{p \text{ people}} = \dfrac{22\text{ pancakes}}{8\text{ people}}$  $8 \cdot 55 = 22 \cdot p\qquad$[[☃ explanation 1]]
$p = \dfrac{440}{22}~~~~~~~~~~~$ Divide both sides by $22$.
Rita can serve $20$ people with $55$ pancakes.

question.content: Stan's cookie recipe makes $24$ cookies and calls for exactly $384$ sprinkles.  He is wondering how many sprinkles $(p)$ he will need to make $60$ cookies. He assumes each cookie will have the same number of sprinkles.  **How many sprinkles does Stan need to make $60$ cookies?**   sprinkles

hints.content: We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{\text{Sprinkles needed for 24 cookies}}{\text{Sprinkles needed for 60 cookies}} = \dfrac{\text{24 cookies}}{\text{60 cookies}}$
Substituting values from the problem, we get this:  $\dfrac{384 \text{ sprinkles}}{p\text{ sprinkles}} = \dfrac{24 \text{ cookies}}{60\text{ cookies}}$
Let's solve for $p$:  $\dfrac{384 \text{ sprinkles}}{p\text{ sprinkles}} = \dfrac{24 \text{ cookies}}{60\text{ cookies}}$  $60 \cdot 384 = 24 \cdot p\qquad$[[☃ explanation 1]]
$p = \dfrac{23{,}040}{24}~~~~~~~~~~~$ Divide both sides by $24$.
Stan needs $960$ sprinkles to make $60$ cookies.

question.content: Scott likes to run long distances.  He can run $20 \text{ km}$  in $85$ minutes. He wants to know how many minutes $(m)$ it will take him to run $52 \text{ km}$  at the same pace.    **How long will it take Scott to run $52 \text{ km}$?**   minutes

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of kilometers to minutes must be equivalent.
We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{20 \text{ km}}{85 \text{ minutes}}=\dfrac{52 \text{ km}}{m \text{ minutes}}$

We can solve for $m$ by isolating it. Since the two rate expressions are equivalent, their reciprocals are also equivalent.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{m \text{ minutes}}{52 \text{ km}}&=\dfrac{85 \text{ minutes}}{20 \text{ km}} \\\\ m \text{ minutes}&=\dfrac{85 \text{ minutes}}{20 \cancel{\text{ km}}}\cdot{52 \cancel{\text{ km}}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} m&=\dfrac{85}{20}\cdot52 \\\\ &=\dfrac{17\cdot\cancel{5}}{\cancel{4}\cdot\cancel{5}}\cdot(13\cdot\cancel{4}) \\\\ &=17\cdot13 \\\\ &=221 \end{align}$
It will take Scott $221$ minutes to run $52 \text{ km}$.

question.content: Teresa is maintaining a camp fire. She can keep the fire burning for $4$ hours with $6$ logs.  She wants to know how many logs $(y)$ she needs to keep the fire burning for $18$ hours. She assumes all logs are the same.  **How many logs  does Teresa need to maintain the fire for $18$ hours?**   logs

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of logs to hours must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{y\text{ logs}}{18\text{ hours}} = \dfrac{6\text{ logs}}{4\text{ hours}}$

Now, solve the proportion for $y$:   $\begin{align} \dfrac{y}{18} &= \dfrac{6}{4}\qquad \\\\ \dfrac{y}{18} &= \dfrac{3}{2} \\\\ y &= \dfrac{3}{2} \cdot 18 \\\\ y &= \dfrac{3\cdot 18}{2} \\\\ y &= \dfrac{3\cdot \stackrel{9}{\cancel{18}} }{\underset{1}{\cancel2}} \\\\ y &= \dfrac{3 \cdot 9}{1} \\\\ y &= \dfrac{27}{1} \\\\ y &= 27 \end{align}$
Teresa needs $27$ logs to maintain the fire for $18$ hours.

question.content: Ted likes to run long distances.  He can run $20 \text{ km}$ in $95$ minutes. He wants to know how many kilometers $(k)$ he will go if he runs at the same pace for $285$ minutes.   **How far will Ted run in $285$ minutes?**   $\text{km}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of kilometers to minutes must be equivalent.
We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{20 \text{ km}}{95 \text{ minutes}}=\dfrac{k \text{ km}}{285 \text{ minutes}}$
We can solve for $k$ by isolating it.  $k \text{ km}=\dfrac{20 \text{ km}}{95 \cancel{\text{ minutes}}}\cdot285 \cancel{\text{ minutes}}$
$\begin{align} k&=\dfrac{20}{95}\cdot 285 \\\\ &=\dfrac{20}{\cancel{95}}\cdot(\cancel{95}\cdot3) \\\\ &=20\cdot3 \\\\ &=60 \end{align}$
Ted will run $60\text{ km}$ in $285$ minutes.

question.content: Liliana used $4$ power crystals to open $14$ portals. Opening the portals uses up the power. She wants to know how many portals $(z)$ she can open with $10$ power crystals.  **How many portals can Liliana open with $10$ power crystals?**   portals

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of power crystals to portals must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{z\text{ portals}}{10\text{ crystals}} = \dfrac{14\text{ portals}}{4\text{ crystals}}$

Now, solve the proportion for $z$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{z}{10} &= \dfrac{14}{4}\qquad \\\\ \dfrac{z}{10} &= \dfrac{7}{2} \\\\ z &= \dfrac{7}{2} \cdot 10 \\\\ z &= \dfrac{7\cdot 10}{2} \\\\ z &= \dfrac{7\cdot \stackrel{5}{\cancel{10}} }{\underset{1}{\cancel2}} \\\\ z &= \dfrac{7 \cdot 5}{1} \\\\ z &= \dfrac{35}{1} \\\\ z &= 35 \end{align}$
Liliana can open $35$ portals with $10$ power crystals.

question.content: Jovie is maintaining a camp fire. She has kept the fire steadily burning for $10$ hours with $15$ logs.  She wants to know how many hours $(h)$ she could have kept the fire going with $9$ logs. She assumes all logs are the same.  **How many hours can Jovie keep the fire going with $9$ logs?**   hours

hints.content: We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{\text{Fire duration with 9 logs}}{\text{Fire duration with 15 logs}} = \dfrac{\text{9 logs}}{15\text{ logs}}$
Substituting values from the problem, we get this:  $\dfrac{h\text{ hours}}{10\text{ hours}} = \dfrac{9\text{ logs}}{15\text{ logs}}$

Solve for $h$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{h}{10} &= \dfrac{9}{15} \\\\\\ \dfrac{h}{10} &= \dfrac{3}{5} \\\\\\ h &= \dfrac{3}{5} \cdot 10 \\\\\\ h &= \dfrac{3\cdot 10}{5} \\\\\\ h &= \dfrac{3\cdot \stackrel{2}{\cancel{10}}}{\underset{1}{\cancel{5}}} \\\\\\ h &= \dfrac{6}{1}\\\\\\ h &= 6 \end{align}$
Jovie can keep the fire going for $6$ hours with $9$ logs.

question.content: Sam used $6$ loaves of elf bread on an $8$ day hiking trip. He wants to know how many loaves of elf bread $(b)$ he should pack for a $12$ day hiking trip if he eats the same amount of bread each day.  **How many loaves of elf bread should Sam pack for a $12$ day trip?**   loaves

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of loaves to days must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{b\text{ loaves}}{12\text{ days}} = \dfrac{6\text{ loaves}}{8\text{ days}}$

Now, solve the proportion for $b$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{b}{12} &= \dfrac{6}{8}\qquad \\\\ \dfrac{b}{12} &= \dfrac{3}{4} \\\\ b &= \dfrac{3}{4} \cdot 12 \\\\ b &= \dfrac{3\cdot 12}{4} \\\\ b &= \dfrac{3\cdot \stackrel{3}{\cancel{12}} }{\underset{1}{\cancel4}} \\\\ b &= \dfrac{3 \cdot 3}{1} \\\\ b &= \dfrac{9}{1} \\\\ b &= 9 \end{align}$
Sam should pack $9$ loaves of elf bread for a $12$ day trip.

question.content: Mika can eat $21$ hot dogs in $6$ minutes. She wants to know how many minutes $(m)$ it would take her to eat $35$ hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.   **How many minutes would Mika need to eat $35$ hot dogs?**   minutes

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of hot dogs to minutes must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{21 \text{ hot dogs}}{6\text{ mins}} = \dfrac{35\text{ hot dogs}}{m\text{ mins}}$
Let's solve for $m$:  $\dfrac{21 \text{ hot dogs}}{6\text{ mins}} = \dfrac{35\text{ hot dogs}}{m\text{ mins}}$  $m \cdot 21 = 35 \cdot 6\qquad$[[☃ explanation 1]]
$m = \dfrac{210}{21}~~~~~~~~~~~$ Divide both sides by $21$.
Mika would need $10$ minutes to eat $35$ hot dogs.

question.content: Yoku is putting on sunscreen. He uses $2\text{ ml}$ to cover $50\text{ cm}^2$ of his skin. He wants to know how many milliliters of sunscreen $(c)$ he needs to cover $325\text{ cm}^2$ of his skin.  **How many milliliters of sunscreen does Yoku need to cover $325 \text{ cm}^2$ of his skin?**   $\text{ml}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of milliliters to square centimeters must be equivalent.

Let's use a table to see how many square centimeters of skin is covered with one milliliter of sunscreen.  Skin ($\text{cm}^2$) | Sunscreen ($\text{mL}$) :-: | :-: $50$ | $2$ $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{2}$ | $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{2}$ $\purpleD{25}$ | $1$  One milliliter of sunscreen covers $\purpleD{25} \text{ cm}^2$ of Yoku's skin.

Now, we can use this rate to solve for how many millileters of sunscreen is needed to cover $325 \text{ cm}^2$ of skin.  Skin ($\text{cm}^2$) | Sunscreen ($\text{mL}$) :-: | :-: $50$ | $2$ $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{2}$ | $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{2}$ $\purpleD{25}$ | $1$ $\downarrow \times \dfrac{325}{\purpleD{25}}$ | $\downarrow \times \dfrac{325}{\purpleD{25}}$ ${325}$ | $c$  $c=1\times\dfrac{325}{\purpleD{25}}=13$
Yoku needs $13 \text{ ml}$ of sunscreen to cover $325 \text{ cm}^2$ of his skin.

question.content: Rachel earned $\$34$ in $4$ hours at her job today. She wants to know how much she could earn $(e)$ tomorrow if she works $10$ hours at the same hourly rate.   **How much will Rachel earn in $10$ hours?**  $\$$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of earnings to hours must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{\$34}{4\text{ hours}} = \dfrac{\$e}{10\text{ hours}}$

Now, solve the proportion for $e$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{34}{4} &= \dfrac{e}{10}\qquad \\\\ \dfrac{17}{2} &= \dfrac{e}{10} \\\\ \dfrac{e}{10} &= \dfrac{17}{2} \\\\ e &= \dfrac{17}{2} \cdot 10 \\\\ e &= \dfrac{17\cdot 10}{2} \\\\ e &= \dfrac{17\cdot \stackrel{5}{\cancel{10}} }{\underset{1}{\cancel2}} \\\\ e &= \dfrac{17 \cdot 5}{1} \\\\ e &= \dfrac{85}{1} \\\\ e &= 85 \end{align}$
Rachel will earn $\$85$ in $10$ hours.

question.content: Mandy works construction. She knows that a $5$ meter long metal bar has a mass of $40 \text{ kg}$. Mandy wants to figure out the mass $(w)$ of a bar made out of the same metal that is $3$ meters long and the same thickness.  **What is the mass of the shorter bar?**   $\text{kg}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of kilograms to meters must be equivalent.

Let's use a table to see the mass of a one-meter-long metal bar.  Mass ($\text{kg}$) | Length ($\text{m}$) :-:|:-: $40$ | $5$ $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{5}$ | $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{5}$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $1$  The mass of a one-meter-long metal bar is $\purpleD{8} \text{ kg}$.

Now, we can use this rate to solve for the mass of a $3$ meter long metal bar.  Mass ($\text{kg}$) | Length ($\text{m}$) :-:|:-: $40$ | $5$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $1$ $\downarrow \times 3$ | $\downarrow \times 3$ $w$ | $3$  $w=\purpleD{8}\times3=24$
The mass of the shorter bar is $24 \text{ kg}$.

question.content: Pamela drove her car $99$ kilometers and used $9$ liters of fuel. She wants to know how many kilometers $(k)$ she can drive with $12$ liters of fuel. She assumes the relationship between kilometers and fuel is proportional.  **How many kilometers can Pamela drive with $12$ liters of fuel?**   $\text{km}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of kilometers to liters must be equivalent.

Let's use a table to see how far Pamela can drive with one liter of fuel.  Distance ($\text{km}$) | Fuel ($\text{L}$) :-:|:-: $99$ | $9$ $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{9}$ | $\downarrow \times \dfrac{1}{9}$ $\purpleD{11}$ | $1$  Pamela can drive $\purpleD{11} \text{ km}$ on one liter of fuel.

Now, we can use this rate to solve for how many kilometers Pamela can drive with $12$ liters of fuel.  Distance ($\text{km}$) | Fuel ($\text{L}$) :-:|:-: $99$ | $9$ $\purpleD{11}$ | $1$ $\downarrow \times 12$ | $\downarrow \times 12$ $k$ | $12$  $k=\purpleD{11}\times12=132$
Pamela can drive $132 \text{ km}$ with $12$ liters of fuel.

question.content: Maddy is carrying a $5$ liter jug of sports drink that weighs $7.5\text{ kg}$. She wants to know how many kilograms a $2$ liter jug of sports drink would weigh $(w)$. She assumes the relationship between volume and weight is proportional.  **What is the weight of the $2$ liter jug?**   $\text{kg}$

hints.content: We're dealing with a proportional relationship, so each ratio of liters to kilograms must be equivalent.
Here's one way to write the proportion:  $\dfrac{w\text{ kg}}{2\text{ liters}} = \dfrac{7.5\text{ kg}}{5\text{ liters}}$
Now, solve the proportion for $w$:  $\begin{align} \dfrac{w}{2} &= \dfrac{7.5}{5}\qquad \\\\ w &= \dfrac{7.5}{5} \cdot 2 \\\\ w &= \dfrac{15}{5} \\\\ w &= 3 \end{align}$
At this rate, a $2$ liter jug weighs $3\text{ kg}$.

question.content: Kwesi is putting on sunscreen. He uses $3\text{ ml}$ to cover $45 \text{ cm}^2$ of his skin. He wants to know how many milliliters of sunscreen $(g)$ he needs to cover $240\text{ cm}^2$ of his skin. He assumes the relationship between milliliters of sunscreen and area is proportional.  **How many milliliters of sunscreen does Kwesi need to cover $240 \text{ cm}^2$ of his skin?**   $\text{ml}$

hints.content: We can set up a proportion like this:  $\dfrac{\text{45 cm}^2}{\text{240 cm}^2} = \dfrac{\text{Sunscreen needed to cover 45 cm}^2}{\text{Sunscreen needed to cover 240 cm}^2}$
Substituting values from the problem, we get this:  $\dfrac{45\text{ cm}^2}{240\text{ cm}^2} = \dfrac{3\text{ ml}}{g\text{ ml}}$
Let's solve for $g$:  $\dfrac{45\text{ cm}^2}{240\text{ cm}^2} = \dfrac{3\text{ ml}}{g\text{ ml}}$  $g \cdot 45 = 3 \cdot 240\qquad$[[☃ explanation 1]]
$g = \dfrac{720}{45}~~~~~~~~~~~$ Divide both sides by $45$.
Kwesi needs $16 \text{ ml}$ of sunscreen to cover $240 \text{ cm}^2$ of his skin.
